journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures

title-group.article-title: Interaction of a vortex pair with a flexible plate in an ideal quiescent fluid

article-meta.aff: 1Mechanical and Mechatronics Engineering Department, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, ON, Canada
2Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Polytechnic Institute of New York University, Six MetroTech Center, Brooklyn, NY, USA

author-notes.corresp: Maurizio Porfiri, Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Polytechnic Institute of New York University, Six MetroTech Center, Brooklyn, NY 11201, USA. Email: mporfiri@poly.edu

article-meta.issue-title: Special Topical Issue on Nonlinear Energy Harvesting

abstract.p: The coupled interaction of a cantilevered Kirchhoff–Love plate with two vortex filaments of equal and opposite circulation in an infinite incompressible, inviscid, and irrotational fluid domain is investigated. The vortices initially advect toward the cantilevered plate, which is oriented perpendicular to the direction of propagation of the vortex pair and undergoes cylindrical bending. As the pair approaches the plate, the pressure field induced by the vortices deflects the plate and initiates vibration of the structure. The vibration of the structure, in turn, alters the path of the two vortices. The level of interaction depends on the vortex circulation and on the ratio of the plate inertia to the fluid inertia, termed the mass ratio. In general, the vortices tend to pass around the plate and eventually advect away from the plate, albeit with a modified trajectory, which depends on the strength of the fluid and structure coupling. The energy imparted to the plate increases with increasing vortex circulation and decreasing mass ratio. The findings of this study provide an initial framework for assessing the energy that can be imparted to a plate for energy harvesting purposes by coherent fluid structures in the absence of viscous effects.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Recent advancements in lightweight smart materials have fostered scientific and technological breakthroughs in small-scale energy harvesting for powering low-consumption electronic devices (Erturk and Inman, 2011; Mateu and Moll, 2005). Currently, explored energy harvesting modalities include temperature gradients (Guyomar et al., 2009), human motion (Mitcheson et al., 2008), and ambient vibration (Aureli et al., 2010; Sodano et al., 2004). In the case of mechanical vibrations in fluids, it is almost categorically the case that the encompassing fluid acts as a viscous damper, reducing the vibration amplitude and thus the energy scavenged (Aureli et al., 2010; Aureli and Porfiri, 2010; Brufau-Penella et al., 2008; Tiwari et al., 2008).

Few research efforts have thus far explored the feasibility of using smart materials for harvesting energy directly from fluid motion, that is, considering the fluid as a source of energy instead of a passive damper. For example, the concept of traditional windmills is used to design piezoelectric-based energy harvesting devices in the study by Myers et al. (2007). The “energy harvesting eel” is a piezoelectric strip placed in the wake of a bluff body in the direction of the cross flow (Allen and Smits, 2001; Taylor et al., 2001). The Karman vortex street formed by the bluff body produces a time-varying pressure load on the strip, which, in turn, causes the strip to harmonically deform. The deformation of the strip induces an electric current that can be used to extract electrical energy. A similar configuration is explored in the study by Akaydin et al. (2010) to harvest energy in a turbulent boundary layer. The flutter instability of a “flapping flag” has been exploited in Giacomello and Porfiri (2011) to harvest energy from a fluid by directly attaching an electroactive polymer to the flag. As the flag flutters, the mechanical energy due to the fluid–structure interaction of the flag and the cross flow is transformed into electrical energy. Flutter instabilities are also considered in the study by Bryant and Garcia (2011) and Erturk et al. (2010), where piezoelectric energy harvesting from the flutter of airfoils is demonstrated. An alternative method for piezoelectric energy harvesting from flow-induced self-oscillation is presented in the study by St Clair et al. (2010).

Coherent fluid structures, perhaps most commonly exemplified by vortex rings (Shariff and Leonard, 1992), are still largely untapped energy sources despite their ubiquity in the environment. They stem from such disparate sources as a flapping fish tail (Fish and Lauder, 2006), jellyfish and squid propulsion (Dabiri, 2009), and the starting of a fluid jet (Krueger and Gharib, 2003). The energy associated with vortex rings is directly related to the vortex ring circulation and geometric parameters (Gharib et al., 1998; Shariff and Leonard, 1992). While this specific relationship depends upon the core structure, in general, the energy increases with increasing vortex ring circulation. This total energy includes the kinetic energy of the ring itself, as well as energy associated with the structure of the core (Saffman, 1995; Sullivan et al., 2008). The relationship between the vortex ring behavior and core vorticity distribution has led to considerable research on vortex ring formation and pinch-off mechanisms (see Gharib et al., 1998; Mohseni et al., 2001; Saffman, 1995).

Harvesting energy from vortices requires these coherent structures to interact with a solid body that either hosts a smart material or is a smart material itself. Spawned by academic interest and practical applications, considerable research efforts have been devoted to the interaction of coherent fluid structures with rigid bodies, typically walls (see Cheng et al., 2010, Chu et al., 1993; Lim, 1989; Naguib and Koochesfahani, 2004). In the inviscid limit, such an interaction is exemplified by the classical problem in potential flow theory of vortices approaching and being diverted by an infinite rigid wall (Milne-Thomson, 1996). In this simple case, the pressure field induced by the traveling vortices does not result into a mechanical motion or deformation since the wall is rigid and fixed. On the other hand, if the structure is free to move or compliant, the disturbance induced by the pressure field generated by the vortices results into complex dynamic interactions. Similar interactions are, for example, important in understanding animal locomotion (Childress, 1981; Lighthill, 1960; Pedley and Hill, 1999).

The focus of the current study is on the energy exchange between coherent fluid structures in the absence of a free stream and a deformable plate for potential energy harvesting applications. Specifically, we focus on the interaction of a vortex pair in an otherwise quiescent ideal, two-dimensional, irrotational fluid with a cantilevered plate. Vortex shedding and instability mechanisms employed to elicit structural deformation in previous studies (see Allen and Smits, 2001; Giacomello and Porfiri, 2011), are absent in this case. Figure 1 illustrates a typical instance of application of theoretical and computational findings from this study. In this figure, we report an illustrative flow visualization experiment for a vortex ring that impacts a thin electroactive strip made of ionic polymer–metal composite (Chen and Tan, 2008; Nemat-Nasser, 2002; Porfiri, 2009; Shahinpoor and Kim, 2001; Wallmersperger et al., 2007). The demonstration consists of a syringe with the end removed to act as a piston–cylinder filled with dyed fluid. A high-speed video camera is used to record the fluid motion and the vibration of the strip. When the plunger is actuated, a vortex ring is produced in the quiescent fluid. As the vortex ring travels, energy is imparted to the electroactive strip that in turn deforms producing an electrical signal that may be used for energy harvesting. The flow visualization experiment is meant only as an illustration, as the flow field is three dimensional and viscosity is obviously present. The focus of this article, rather, is on a two-dimensional problem where we neglect the effect of viscosity in order to analytically obtain a first-order estimate of the energy transfer from the fluid to the structure. Furthermore, we neglect the finite core size of the vortices and replace them with potential flow point vortices. Thus, we assess the energy that can be imparted to the structure solely due to the kinetic energy of the coherent fluid structures in the absence of any damping, be it viscous or structural.

caption.p: Flow visualization images of a vortex ring impacting a cantilevered strip.

sec.p: The manuscript is organized as follows: section “Problem formulation” introduces the mathematical model; the solution procedure is developed in section “Solution procedure”; results are presented in section “Results”; salient remarks about the derived solution are presented in section “Remarks”; and section “Summary” summarizes and concludes the document. Mathematical details are presented in Appendices 1 and 2.

sec.title: Problem formulation
sec.p:
We consider a cantilevered plate of length
L
and thickness
h
submersed in an ideal fluid. The x-axis is taken along the length of the undeformed plate, and the origin is placed at the midpoint of the plate in its resting position. The plate is fixed at
x = − L / 2
and free at
x = L / 2
. We assume that the plate length is much larger than its thickness and that it undergoes pure cylindrical bending with small deformations. That is, the plate configuration is entirely defined by its deflection
δ ( x , t )
along the y direction, which is normal to the plate in its resting state (see Figure 2). In addition, we assume that the plate material is elastic and isotropic. With these assumptions, the plate is modeled as a Kirchhoff–Love plate (see Mansfield, 1989)

Note that the pressure jump is computed as the difference between the fluid pressure on the plate face oriented in the positive y direction and the face oriented in the negative y direction (see Michelin and Llewellyn Smith, 2009b). That is, a positive pressure jump causes a negative plate deflection. caption.p: Schematic of the plate and the vortex pair.

sec.p:
The surrounding fluid is modeled as ideal, that is, incompressible and inviscid, quiescent, and irrotational. Moreover, the fluid motion is assumed to be two dimensional and confined to the xy-plane where the plate vibration is defined. The irrotational condition allows the fluid velocity to be expressed as the gradient of a scalar potential function. Imposing the incompressibility condition yields Laplace’s equation as the governing equation for the fluid motion. We construct the velocity field by superposing two vortex filaments of equal and opposite circulation
Γ
and a vortex sheet with variable strength
γ ( x , t )
to model the influence of the plate. Introducing the complex coordinate
z = x + iy
and velocity
w = u − iv
, where
u
and
v
are the velocity components in the
x
and
y
directions, respectively, we write the total velocity field (see Michelin and Llewellyn Smith, 2009a) as

where
z
k
corresponds to the position of the kth vortex (see Figure 2). The first term on the right-hand side of equation (5) corresponds to the contribution from the two free vortices, while the integral term is the contribution from the bound vortex sheet representing the plate. Note that positive circulation induces counterclockwise fluid flow. At time
t = 0
, the vortex sheet is 0 everywhere, that is,
γ ( x , 0 ) = 0
. By Kelvin’s circulation theorem, then

for all time. Nondimensionalizing the fluid velocity as
w

The vortices advect with the local velocity field yielding equations of motion for the vortices

The boundary conditions on the fluid require that the component of the fluid velocity normal to the vortex sheet must match the plate velocity. Additionally, the fluid must come to rest and the pressure must go to zero at infinity. The conditions at infinity are satisfied automatically by the velocity field in equation (7), while the normal velocity condition on the plate requires that

where
− ∫ ( · )
is the Cauchy principal value integral and
ℜ { · }
indicates the real part of the complex variable. The pressure jump across the plate can be computed using Bernoulli’s equation as (see Michelin and Llewellyn Smith, 2009a)

The velocity in the last term of equation (10) is the difference in the tangential velocity across the plate. For the remainder of this document, the hat is dropped and all variables are assumed nondimensional unless otherwise stated. We comment that different nondimensionalizations of the governing equations are possible, and a different selection is presented in section “Comments on the nondimensionalization scheme” for completeness.

Solving the set of nonlinearly coupled differential equations in equation (14) requires that the integrals in equation (15) be computed, in particular, the integral involving the pressure distribution in equation (15c). From equations (25) and (26), we define the following matrices
By using the definitions in equation (27), equation (15c) yields

The first term in equation (28) is an added mass term; the third term is of the form of a damping term, even though there is no fluidic or structural damping in the system; and the remaining two terms are general forcing terms due to the vortex pair. The integral in equations (27a) and (27b) is computed using equation (43) from Appendix 2. A closed form solution to the integral in equations (27c) and (27d) is presented in equation (44) in Appendix 2.

The full solution to the posed problem is obtained by simultaneously solving equations (32) and (36). This can be accomplished numerically by writing equation (32) as a system of first-order equations and using, for example, the Runge–Kutta algorithm or other integrators (see Hoffman, 2001; Press et al., 2002). Validation of the solution procedure is discussed in section “Limit as
μ → ∞
, validation with a rigid plate” by comparing the present solution when the plate is rigid with the canonical solution of a vortex pair approaching an infinite wall.

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
Ten vortex circulation magnitudes
Γ = 0 . 125 , 0 . 25 , 0 . 375 , 0 . 5 , 0 . 625 , 0 . 75 , 0 . 875 , 1 . 0 , 1 . 25 ,
and
1 . 5
are examined for a mass ratio of
μ = 50
. In all cases, the vortices are initialized at
z
1
( t = 0 ) = 0 . 1 − 3 i
and
z
2
( t = 0 ) = − 0 . 1 − 3 i
(see Figure 2), which prescribes an initial vortex spacing of
a = 0 . 2
, placing the midpoint between the two vortices on the y-axis, that is, at the beam center. The line connecting the vortex centers is initially parallel to the undeflected plate. The plate is at rest at
t = 0
, that is,
δ ( x , 0 ) =
δ
·
( x , 0 ) = 0
and
γ ( x , 0 ) = 0
. The initial advection velocity of the vortex pair is
V
pair
( t = 0 ) = Γ / a
. The solution presented herein is obtained using
N
γ
= 30
and
N
δ
= 15
. To expedite the computation, a reduced set of three plate vibration modes is used. Since equation (32) is formulated in modal coordinates
δ

to a
(

− 2 ) ×
N

N

is the number of modes employed in the solution procedure. The sensitivity of the solution to the choice of

and

ω
1

ω
2

ω
3
in equation (33c) differ from the exact values obtained from Meirovitch (2000), by less than
0 . 0005 %
.

Both the mass ratio and circulation strength influence the degree of coupling between the plate and the fluid. In the following subsections, we discuss the physics of the coupled vortex/plate interaction for
μ = 50
at the aforementioned 10 values of
Γ
. A quantitative discussion of impact of lowering the mass ratio, that is, increasing the degree of coupling, is presented in section “Comments on the impact of lowering the mass ratio.” Further discussion on the relation between the dimensionless parameters and the coupling of the fluid with the structure is presented in section “Comments on the nondimensionalization scheme.”

sec.title: Vortex/plate interaction
sec.p:
General characteristics of the vortex pair/plate coupling for
μ = 50
are highlighted using
Γ = 1 . 5
as a representative case. The characteristics of the interaction are presented, followed by details of both the vortex pair and plate behaviors.

Snapshots of the coupled plate/vortex interaction are detailed in Figure 3. In the figure, the left column shows the plate position (black line), with the displacement and the vortex positions (dots). The middle column shows the plate shape
δ ( x , t )
in more detail. The right column displays the differential pressure load
[
[ p ]
]
( x , t )
acting on the plate. Note that the scale of the ordinates on the plots in the middle and right columns are not the same from row to row. As the vortices approach the plate from below, the induced velocity field results in a higher pressure on the bottom of the plate in comparison with the top of the plate due to fluid stagnation on the bottom of the plate. This corresponds to a negative value of
[
[ p ]
]
, as shown in the pressure distribution in Figure 3(a). The pressure loading causes the plate to deflect upward, away from the vortex pair. Note that herein we refer to the “bottom” of the plate as the plate surface whose normal vector points in the negative y direction in the undeflected state, while the “top” of the plate is the opposing surface.

caption.p:
Snapshots of the vortex location with respect to the plate (left column), the plate shape
δ ( x , t )
(middle column), and the differential pressure on the plate
[
[ p ]
]
( x , t )
(right column), for
μ = 50
and
Γ = 1 . 5
at subsequent instants of time (a) – (f).

sec.p: The magnitude of the plate deflection continues to increase as the vortices pass around the ends of the plate (see Figure 3(d)). Once the vortices are on the other side of the plate, the pressure loading on the plate at the vortex locations changes sign, as evidenced in Figure 3(e). In Figure 3(f), the vortices have reconvened on the other side of the plate and started to advect away. The magnitude of the pressure loading on the plate has decreased considerably. By this time, the plate shape has become more complex, that is, multiple modes are involved, and the pressure loading on the plate is due in part to the vorticity distribution in the vortex sheet collocated with the plate. In other words, the velocity field induced by the plate is significantly contributing to the pressure loading on the plate. As the vortices propagate away from the plate (not shown), the pressure loading magnitude on the plate decreases substantially, and the plate is set into undamped vibratory motion. The pressure loading on the plate eventually is simply due to the plate motion itself, and the plate motion reaches a steady oscillation.

sec.title: Vortex pair behavior
sec.p:
Figure 4 shows the paths of the vortices with an overlay of the plate rest position for
μ = 50
and
Γ = 1 . 5
. The corresponding
x
and
y
components of the vortex positions are plotted versus time in Figure 5. The vortices initially approach the plate on a trajectory perpendicular to the rest orientation of the plate. When near the plate, they split apart, each traveling around a different end of the structure. The vortex motions, as they approach the plate, are similar to the well-known propagation of vortices near a wall in classical potential flow (see Milne-Thomson, 1996). The case of
μ → ∞
is presented in section “Limit as
μ → ∞
, validation with a rigid plate.” For
μ = 50
and
Γ = 1 . 5
, the vortices reach their peak separation, that is, they pass around the ends of the plate, at
t = 3 . 41
(see also Figure 3(d)). Once around the ends of the plate, the vortices converge toward each other. The velocity fields induced by the converging vortices eventually cause the pair to propagate away from the plate, albeit with an altered trajectory in comparison to their approach path. Close inspection of Figure 4 shows that the midpoint between the vortices shifts slightly in the negative
x
direction. Symmetry in the behavior of the two vortices is broken by the asymmetric plate deflection. A more visually apparent manifestation of this asymmetry is offered by the change in the vortex pair trajectory after interacting with the plate. The most significant impact of the plate on the vortices occurs when the vortex pair is in close proximity to the plate, namely,
ℑ { z } ≈ 0
, which occurs for
2 . 5 < t < 4 . 5
in this case. When not in close proximity to the plate, the vortex pair largely propagates as it would in an infinite fluid medium with no obstacles.

x

x = 1
and then switch the direction after passing around the plate tip. After the vortices reconvene, their final trajectory is different from the initial approach trajectory of the pair. For the case considered, the final trajectory angle is
− 2 .
29

.

Trajectory of the vortex pair in degrees as a function of time for

and
Γ = 1 . 5
.

sec.p:
The distance between the centers of each vortex
|
z
1
−
z
2
|
is shown in Figure 7(a). The dimensionless separation is initially
a = 0 . 2
. The vortices remain at approximately this separation until encountering the plate, at which point the distance grows to
2 . 09
at
t = 3 . 32
, corresponding to the time at which the vortices pass around the ends of the plate (see Figure 3(d)). When the vortices reconvene on the other side of the plate, they do not regain their original separation distance, but rather end up closer together. For
μ = 50
and
Γ = 1 . 5
, the distance between the two vortices long after the interaction with the plate is
0 . 191
, which represents a decrease of
4 . 4 %
from the initial separation (see the inset in Figure 7(a)).

caption.p:
(a) Distance between the vortices (dashed line in inset shows initial vortex separation) and (b) their propagation speed (solid line is vortex 1 and the dashed line is vortex 2) for
μ = 50
and
Γ = 1 . 5
. Inset graphs show details during interaction.

sec.p:
The speed of the two vortices is plotted in Figure 7(b). Initially, both vortices have a speed of
Γ / a = 1 . 2
. As they interact with the plate, their speed initially decreases as they begin to diverge and then increases as they approach and pass around the tips of the plate. The vortices then slow again as they reconvene. The plate deflection causes the speed of the two vortices to differ, with vortex 1 that passes around the fixed end generally moving faster during the vortex pair divergence and subsequent convergence. This is more readily apparent in the inset figure in Figure 7(b), which zooms in on the range
1 < t < 6
. As the vortices propagate away from the plate, they once again behave as a unit. The final convection speed of the vortex pair is higher than the initial speed due to the decreased separation between the pair, as shown in Figure 7(a). For this case, the final advection velocity is
104 . 6 %
of the initial speed. The increase in speed is due to the “kick” the vortices get by the vortex sheet due to their closer proximity to the plate after they pass around the edges of the plate. This is likely tied to the relative time scales of the vibration period of the plate and the time it takes the vortices to travel around the plate.

sec.title: Plate behavior
sec.p: The tip deflection of the free end of the cantilever plate is presented in Figure 8(a) as a function of time. As the vortices approach the plate, the pressure field induced by the fluid motion causes the plate to deflect, setting the plate into motion, as discussed in section “Vortex/plate interaction.” The plate motion, in turn, influences the paths of the vortices, as shown in Figure 4. Note that the plate tip motion is not monochromatic due to the contribution from the higher order vibration modes of the plate. Longer time series demonstrate that the plate continues to vibrate after the influence of the vortices is negligible.

caption.p:
(a) Deflection of the free plate end
δ ( 1 , t )
and (b) the energy contained in the vibrating plate as functions of time for
μ = 50
and
Γ = 1 . 5
.

sec.p:
Figure 8(b) plots the total energy of the plate. The total energy of the plate, nondimensionalized by
B /
L
0
, consists of both potential energy associated with material strain and kinetic energy and is given by

By using equations (15) and (31), this quantity can be approximated using the modal coordinate vector
δ
~
as

When the vortices are approaching the plate, yet still far from it, the plate deflection and velocity are very small, and thus, the plate energy is negligible. As the vortex pair approaches, the plate deflection and velocity increase dramatically, leading to a rise in the total plate energy. The vortex/plate interaction continues to impart energy to the plate until approximately the time at which the vortices pass around the ends of the plate. Interestingly, once the plate energy reaches a maximum, it stays at that value as the plate continues to vibrate and the vortices advect away. Bidirectional energy exchange still occurs locally between the plate and the fluid, which results in small fluctuations in the plate energy, though the mean value is stationary.

sec.title:
Influence of vortex circulation
Γ
sec.p:
Vortex circulation is a measure of vortex strength. A higher vortex circulation results in a stronger velocity field, which, in turn, impacts the pressure field. Increasing the circulation of each vortex in the vortex pair causes a higher advection speed and higher pressure loading on the plate for a given vortex pair position. In this section, the influence of vortex circulation is discussed with
μ
held constant at 50.

The trajectory of the vortex pair for various circulation values is shown in Figure 9(a) as a function of time. The behavior, described for the specific case of
Γ = 1 . 5
in section “Vortex pair behavior,” is similar for all values of the circulation. In all cases, the vortices divert toward the free end of the plate, that is, in the positive x direction. The final deflection angle peaks at an angle of
− 3 .
81
∘
when
Γ = 0 . 5
. This is clearly shown in Figure 9(b), which plots the final trajectory angle as a function of
Γ
. The final deflection angle then decreases as the circulation increases. The minimum is likely due to the relationship between the velocity of the vortices and the frequency of plate vibration. Furthermore, it is likely that in a broadened parameter range, there would be other local minima.

caption.p:
(a) Trajectory of the vortices for various values of circulation and (b) the final trajectory angle for
μ = 50
.

sec.p:
The speed of vortex 1 is shown in Figure 10(a). As previously mentioned, increasing the circulation increases the initial vortex speed. The ratio of the final vortex pair advection speed long after interacting with the plate to the initial advection speed is approximately 1 for
Γ = 0 . 125
and then increases with increasing vortex circulation up to
Γ = 0 . 5
, as shown in Figure 10(b). The speed ratio fluctuates slightly, first decreasing, then increasing, and then decreasing again as
Γ
increases beyond a value of
0 . 5
. For a broad range of vortex circulations, the final advection speed is approximately
105 %
of the initial speed.

caption.p:
(a) Speed of vortex 1 and (b) the ratio of the final advection speed to the initial advection speed for various values of
Γ
for
μ = 50
.

sec.p:
The maximum tip deflection of the plate as a function of circulation is presented in Figure 11(a). The vibration amplitude monotonically increases with circulation. For
Γ < 0 . 5
, the plate vibration is dominated by the first vibration mode. As
Γ
increases, the contribution from other modes becomes important, as evidenced by the plate shapes presented in Figure 3 for
Γ = 1 . 5
. Figure 11(a) illustrates that stronger vortices incite larger vibration amplitudes due to the stronger induced pressure fields. The increased plate deflection is further evidenced in Figure 11(b), which shows the energy of the plate for various circulation values. As expected, the energy imparted to the plate is larger when interacting with stronger vortices, though it does level off as
Γ
increases.

caption.p:
(a) Maximum tip deflection and (b) the plate energy for various values of circulation with
μ = 50
.

sec.p:
The average final energy of the plate
F
, defined as the mean of the plate energy once it has plateaued and practically computed by time averaging the plate energy once the vortices have advected away from the beam (see Figure 11(b)), normalized by
Γ
2
is presented in Figure 12 for various values of
Γ
. In the frame of reference of the vortices, there exists a closed oval-shaped streamline that can be used to define the “body” of the vortex pair (see Milne-Thomson, 1996). The kinetic energy of the vortex pair per unit length in dimensional variables is
C ρ
a
2
( Γ / a
)
2
, where
C
is a constant. Thus, the vortex energy is directly proportional to
Γ
2
, and Figure 12, therefore, provides an indication of the portion of the initial vortex energy that is transferred to the plate. Note that the circulation value used in the normalization of
F
in Figure 12 is dimensionless and that a viscous vortex ring will have energy associate with the core structure as well. At
μ = 50
and
Γ > 0 . 375
, the percentage of the vortex pair energy imparted to the plate is nearly constant. We further note that while the vortex “body” conserves kinetic energy during the interaction with the plate, it does so by shrinking in size, thus reducing the advected mass
ρ
a
2
, in order to balance the increase in the velocity
Γ / a
of the pair shown in Figure 10(b).

caption.p:
Average final energy of the plate normalized by the vortex pair energy as a function of
Γ
for
μ = 50
.

sec.title: Remarks
sec.p:
This section is reserved for discussions that are pertinent, but not critical, to the discussions in the remainder of the manuscript. We discuss four topics, namely a comparison of the present solution as
μ → ∞
with the well-known potential flow solution of a vortex pair interacting with an infinite wall, the sensitivity of the solution to the number of terms used in the projections onto the basis sets in equations (13) and (18), the quantitative impact of lowering the mass ratio, and lastly a few comments regarding the selected nondimensionalization scheme and its relation to the coupling between the vortex pair and the plate.

sec.title:
Limit as
μ → ∞
, validation with a rigid plate
sec.p:
In the limit as the mass ratio approaches infinity with vortex strength kept finite and the plate initially at rest, the fluid mechanics and structural dynamics are decoupled, and thus, the problem becomes that of a vortex pair approaching a rigid flat plate. Under this condition, we expect the present solution to result in vortex motion that resembles that of a vortex pair approaching an infinite flat wall when the vortices are sufficiently far from the ends of the plate. The solution of a vortex pair approaching a flat wall, or equivalently a vortex in a corner, is a canonical potential flow problem that can be easily solved via the method of images (see Milne-Thomson, 1996). We solve the rigid case plate by fixing
δ ( x , t ) = 0
and integrating equation (36). Figure 13 plots the path and the speed of vortex 1 for
Γ = 1 . 0
and
z
1
( t = 0 ) = 0 . 1 − 3 i
and
z
2
( t = 0 ) = − 0 . 1 − 3 i
as it approaches a rigid flat plate retaining the simulation parameter
N
γ
= 30
. The solution is symmetric about the y-axis, so only vortex 1 is presented. Included on both figures for comparison is the solution for a vortex pair approaching an infinite wall. The two solutions are identical until the vortex nears the end of the finite plate, at which point it diverts around the obstacle before converging with its mate and propagating away from the plate at a exactly the original vortex spacing and speed.

caption.p:
(a) Path and (b) speed of one vortex in a pair approaching a rigid plate. The thick horizontal solid line at
y = 0
in (a) represents the rigid plate, while the thin solid line denotes
z
1
and the dashed line denotes a vortex approaching an infinite wall as opposed to a finite plate.

sec.title:
Sensitivity to
N
γ
,
N
δ
, and
N
m
sec.p:
In practice, the solution procedure described in section “Solution procedure” requires projection of the plate shape and the vorticity distribution onto finite sets of basis functions. As discussed therein, the number of terms used in the projection of the plate shape is governed by
N
δ
, and the number of terms used to project the vorticity is controlled by
N
γ
. Furthermore, to expedite the computation, we solve the posed problem using a reduced set of plate vibration modes
N
m
, as discussed in section “Results.” In this section, we explore the dependence of the solution on the selection of these three parameters, that is,
N
δ
,
N
γ
, and
N
m
. The results presented in section “Results” use
N
δ
= 15
,
N
γ
= 30
, and
N
m
= 3
. The final trajectory of the vortices and the average final plate energy are employed in this section as metrics to assess the sensitivity of the solution to the aforementioned parameters. We use
μ = 50
and
Γ = 1 . 5
as a representative case in this exploration as it exhibits higher order vibration modes.

The sensitivity of the solution to
N
γ
is presented in Figure 14(a), with
N
γ
varying from 5 to 30 in increments of 5 and holding
N
δ
= 15
and
N
m
= 3
. The final vortex trajectory is relatively constant for
N
γ
= 25
and
30
, while the average final plate energy is largely invariant to changes in
N
γ
for
N
γ
≥ 15
. Figure 14(b) presents the impact of
N
δ
on the solution with
N
γ
= 30
and
N
m
= 3
. The solution is not sensitive to this parameter for the full range of values investigated. The total number of modes used in the final computation,
N
m
, has a significant impact on the total time required to obtain a solution. As an example, using a reduced set of three modes in the computation with
N
δ
= 15
and
N
γ
= 30
requires a few hours to run on a single core computer using the NDSolve integrator in Mathematica 8 with all options set as the defaults (see Wolfram Research, Inc., 2010). Increasing this to four modes nearly doubles the run time. Thus, it is apparent that using the smallest
N
m
value possible is highly beneficial from a computational resources perspective. Figure 14(c) shows the sensitivity of the solution to
N
m
in the range of
1 ≤
N
m
≤ 4
with
N
δ
= 15
and
N
γ
= 30
. For two modes and above, the solution does not vary appreciably for the degree of fluid/structure coupling considered in this investigation.

caption.p:
Final vortex pair trajectory (left column) and average final plate energy (right column) for varying values of (a)
N
γ
, (b)
N
δ
, and (c)
N
m
.

sec.p:
The sensitivity analysis demonstrates that for
N
γ
≥ 15
,
N
δ
≥ 8
, and
N
m
≥ 3
, the solution is independent of the parameter values to within
1 %
. The exception being the sensitivity of the final trajectory to
N
γ
, which varies by almost
10 %
between
N
γ
= 25
and
30
. However, energy transfer to the plate changes by less than
1 %
for values greater than
20
. Numerical difficulties were encountered when attempting to use
N
γ
> 30
and
N
m
> 4
.

sec.title: Comments on the impact of lowering the mass ratio
sec.p:
Decreasing the mass ratio generally results in stronger coupling between the fluid and the structure, as shown in equation (29). The increased coupling results in enhanced influence of the plate on the path of the vortex pair. In this section, we discuss the impact of reducing the mass ratio on the quantitative coupling measures, such as vortex trajectory and plate energy, introduced in section “Results.” Specifically, we examine two additional mass ratios of
μ = 10
and
μ = 5
.

We use the case with
μ = 10
and
Γ = 0 . 875
to demonstrate the qualitative impact of reducing the mass ratio on parameters such as vortex path and speed. The vortex pair path in this case is shown in Figure 15. This figure is analogous to Figure 4 presented in section “Results” for
μ = 50
. Figure 15 demonstrates that with increased coupling, the paths of the vortices are significantly diverted due to the interaction with the vibrating plate. The plate motion diverts the paths of the vortices, particularly vortex 1, after it moves around to the “back” side of the plate, resulting in a considerably more skewed trajectory than in the high mass ratio case.

caption.p:
Path of the vortices for
μ = 10
and
Γ = 0 . 875
. The thick horizontal solid line at
y = 0
represents the rest position of the plate. The thin solid line is vortex 1 and the dashed line is vortex 2.

sec.p:
The speed of the vortices and the tip deflection of the plate are presented in Figure 16 as functions of time. The final separation of the two vortices is considerably smaller than the initial separation, resulting in a large increase in the vortex pair speed as they advect away from the plate post-interaction. The speeds of the two vortices are considerably different while they are in close proximity to, and under the strong influence of the plate
4 < t < 9
. The peak speed of vortex 1 is nearly
30 %
greater than the maximum speed of vortex 2. The comparatively large plate displacement (see Figure 16(b)) plays a large role on the fluid velocity field near the tip of the plate, which impacts the velocity of vortex 1 much more so than it does vortex 2. Figure 16(b) shows that the beam vibration is not monochromatic and largely involved the first two fundamental modes whose nondimensional periods are
2 π
and approximately 1.

caption.p:
(a) Propagation speed of the vortices where the solid line is vortex 1 and the dashed line is vortex 2 and (b) the tip deflection of the plate for
μ = 10
and
Γ = 0 . 875
as functions of time.

sec.p:
The ratio of the final to initial vortex speed and maximum tip displacement are presented in Figure 17 for various values of
Γ
at
μ = 5
and
μ = 10
. In Figure 17(a), we observe reducing the mass ratio results in a considerable increase in the final advection speed of the vortices, particularly for the mid-range of
Γ
. For
μ = 10
, vortex pair advection speeds can be increased to nearly
160 %
of the initial propagation speed via the interaction with the plate. This final advection speed is even higher when
μ
is further reduced to a value of 5. The tip deflection as a function of
Γ
is presented in Figure 17(b). This figure shows that the amplitude of the deflection becomes considerable as
μ
decreases. At
μ = 5
, the tip deflection can be up to
50 %
of the plate length at
Γ = 0 . 875
. Higher values of
Γ
did not converge for
μ = 5
. Such a large vibration amplitude severely strains the small amplitude assumption of Kirchhoff–Love plate theory upon which this solution is predicated.

caption.p:
(a) Ratio of final vortex speed to initial vortex speed and (b) maximum tip deflection as functions of
Γ
. Circles correspond to
μ = 5
, while squares denote
μ = 10
.

sec.p:
The final plate energy divided by the initial vortex energy normalized by
Γ
2
is virtually constant over the range considered, except at the lowest value of
Γ = 0 . 125
for both
μ = 5
and
μ = 10
, as shown in Figure 18. Furthermore, comparison with Figure 12 demonstrates that the percentage of the vortex pair energy transferred to the plate is greater for lower values of
μ
at a fixed
Γ
. That is, as the degree of coupling increases, the amount of energy transferred to the plate increases.

caption.p:
Final plate energy normalized by the incoming vortex energy as a function of
Γ
. Circles correspond to
μ = 5
, while squares denote
μ = 10
.

sec.title: Comments on the nondimensionalization scheme
sec.p:
The posed problem is primarily governed by three dimensionless parameters,
μ
,
Γ
^
, and
a /
L
0
, with reference to the hat notation for nondimensionalization introduced in section “Problem formulation.” The first two parameters show up explicitly in equations (3) and (8), respectively. The geometrical parameter,
a /
L
0
, relating the initial vortex separation to the plate length appears as an initial condition. Additional geometric parameters such as the initial vortex pair orientation with respect to the plate rest position may become important under specific configurations. This nondimensionalization scheme is structurally based, that is, the velocity, length, and time scales are derived from plate dynamics as opposed to the fluid dynamics. For the structurally based nondimensionalization, one vibration period of the structure is directly proportional to one unit of dimensionless time. We utilize this nondimensionalization as it facilitates direct comparison of the plate dynamics under the various fluid loading conditions.

An alternative scheme often implemented in flapping flag investigations utilizes flow-based velocity and time scales for nondimensionalization (see Alben and Shelley, 2008; Giacomello and Porfiri, 2011). Fluid-based nondimensionalization typically uses the free stream fluid velocity as the characteristic velocity scale and constructs a convective time scale from the quotient of the length and velocity scales. In the present case, there is no free stream velocity, so the fluid velocity scale is based upon the initial convective velocity of the vortex pair,
V
pair
= Γ / a
. This velocity scale and the associated time scale
L
0
/
V
pair
results in an alternate version of equation (3) containing three dimensionless parameters
μ
1
=
m
s
/ ( ρ
L
0
)
,
μ
2
= B / ( ρ
Γ
2
L
0
)
, and
μ
3
= a /
L
0
, that is

The parameters
μ
1
and
μ
3
are identical to the mass and geometrical ratios, respectively, that show up in the structurally based nondimensionalization, while
μ
2
is a ratio of the restoring force in the plate to the applied fluid loading. It is apparent from equation (39) that the degree of plate/fluid coupling is influenced by all three dimensionless parameters. The dimensionless parameter
Γ
^
appearing in the structurally based nondimensionalization scheme is related to
μ
1
and
μ
2
by
Γ
^
=
μ
1
/
μ
2
. Thus, we observe that both
μ
and
Γ
^
from the current structure-based nondimensionalization impact the degree of coupling between the plate and the fluid. Furthermore,
Γ
^
cannot be changed independently of
μ
.

The final plate energy for all three mass ratios are plotted versus
μ
2
in Figure 19. As with
μ
1
, lower values of
μ
2
are associated with stronger coupling and consequently generally lead to higher plate energy. The data have been fitted with a power law of
0 . 481
μ
2
− 1 . 797
.

caption.p:
Final plate energy for each mass ratio versus
μ
2
. Circles are
μ
1
= 5
, squares are
μ
1
= 10
, and diamonds are
μ
1
= 50
.

sec.title: Summary
sec.p: In this article, we have examined the coupled interaction between a vortex pair propagating via self-induction through an ideal fluid and a thin deformable plate. The level of interaction between the fluid and structure is governed by the circulation of the vortices and the mass ratio of the plate. The pressure field caused by the vortex pair advecting toward the center of the fixed-free cantilever plate causes it to deflect and ultimately vibrate. As the vortices approach the plate, the pressure loading on the plate becomes more substantial and consequently the deflection amplitude increases. Since the entire system is conservative, the plate continues to vibrate indefinitely after the interaction with the vortex pair. The total energy contained in the plate, in the form of potential and kinetic energies, increases as the vortices approach and then plateaus once the vortices pass around the plate. The final mean plate energy generally increases with increasing vortex circulation and with decreasing mass ratio.

Several assumptions are made in the problem formulation. Notably, the fluid is considered ideal, that is, incompressible and inviscid, and irrotational. Thus, there is no viscous dissipation or vorticity shedding. The solid structure is assumed to undergo small displacements, which necessarily precludes membrane stretching and other nonlinear effects from affecting the interaction. Furthermore, three-dimensional effects and vortex shedding are neglected entirely. In a real fluid, viscous effects are expected to become significant as the vortex pair approaches the plate. The vortex pair would induce vorticity on the plate surface, which would interact with the vortex pair, likely preventing the vortices from actually surviving long enough to fully pass around the plate. It is more likely that the vortex pair will be either destroyed or seriously altered by the interaction with the plate (see Allen et al., 2007; Kramer et al., 2007; Parras and Fernandez-Feria, 2007).

The solution presented here yields the energy that can be transferred from a coherent vortex pair structure to a deformable plate in a lossless environment and without structural damping. If the deformable plate is an electroactive polymer or a piezoelectric strip, then the solution can be incorporated into a larger investigation of energy harvesting from fluid motion.

sec.title:
Alternate formulation of
f
k
sec.p:
The exact solution to the integral
f
k
( z )
presented in equation (23) becomes numerically intractable as
k
increases, since each of the two Chebyshev polynomials grows very large and thus taking the difference between them can lead to numerical inaccuracies. This can be mitigated by reformulating equation (23) using the identities

Substituting equations (40) and (41) into equation (23) and rearranging lead to two formulations of
f
k
as

where the top sign in the
±
and
∓
should be used when
ℜ { z } > 0
, and the lower sign version should be used when
ℜ { z } < 0
. The function
G ( z )
is presented in equation (24) while
A
k
is given in equation (22). Equation (42) is well behaved for larger values of
k
and can be well implemented into a numerical solution in place of equation (23).

sec.p: This appendix contains closed form solutions to the various integrals that arise in the problem solution.

The solution to the integral in equation (34) is

fn.p: A Cholesky decomposition of the mass matrix is used in the simulation code to regularize matrix inversions along the lines of Meirovitch (2000: 323).
